repository.corpname: Marist College Archives and Special Collections

did.abstract: The Lowell Thomas Papers encompasses a wide range of materials documenting the life, family, and professional career of Lowell Thomas. These materials include correspondence, administrative and financial documents, manuscripts, printed materials, photographic materials, motion picture films, audio recordings, and memorabilia.
did.langmaterial: The language of the materials is predominately English. Other languages include: Arabic, Chinese, French, German, Hebrew, Hindi, Italian, Spanish and Swedish.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Divided into nine subseries, this series consists of reel-to-reel audio tapes, phonograph records, audio cassettes, and other types of sound recordings. The subseries are arranged by form of material. Subseries 1 - 4 are divided further into sub subseries arranged by subject, and each includes recordings that pertain to Thomas's major professional projects. Information regarding the content of each recording is taken from [the recording's container]. A project to digitize these recordings is on-going. Researchers should consult with the archivist regarding the available digital versions.

acqinfo.p: The Lowell Thomas Papers were donated to Marist College by the Thomas family in 2006.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Lowell Jackson Thomas was born in Woodington, Ohio on 6 April 1892 to two school teachers, Harry G. Thomas and Harriet Wagner Thomas. The family did not remain in Darke County, Ohio for very long because Lowell's father wanted to become a doctor. Harry G. Thomas's pursuit of a medical degree led the family to Kirkman, Iowa where five-year-old Lowell was enrolled in school for the first time. Harry's studies soon led him to the University of Nebraska. Upon graduation, Harry G. Thomas followed his brother's suggestion to begin his medical practice in the twin mining boom towns of Cripple Creek and Victor, Colorado. It was here in the rugged American West that Lowell spent the better part of his childhood and young adult years.

accessrestrict.p: There are no restrictions on this collection

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Description of item, date, location of item in order of series, box number, folder number ], in the Lowell Thomas Papers: Sound Recordings Collection, Archives and Special Collections, James A. Cannavino Library, Marist College.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Collection
arrangement.p: These records are organized into nine series: 1) Reel-to-Reel audio tape, has 16 subseries, 2. Phonograph Records, has eight subseries, 3. Audio Cassettes, has nine subseries, 4) 16 millimeter magnetic tape, has two subseries, 5) SoundScriber recordings, 6) Flexographs, 7) Dictabelt Recordings, 8) Wire Recordings, and 9) 8-Track cartridge

note.p: The Marist College Archives and Special Collections staff wishes to express their deep appreciation to all of the parties that helped the Lowell Thomas Project come to fruition.

scopecontent.p: Series contains Lowell Thomas and the News, The Best Years, Tibet, High Adventure with Lowell Thomas, Flight to Adventure, Lowell Thomas radio inserts, music and song, personalities, Lowell Thomas, Jr., Speeches, Flight to South Pole, banquets, interviews, Alaska, personal, and miscellany.

En route 1. Lowell Thomas, Jr. - Report from Bengal, India to Tibetan border 2. Lowell Thomas, Jr., report from Tehran July 19, 1949 3. Lowell Thomas in plane over Pacific, halfway to Hawaii July 21, 1949 4. Lowell Thomas interviews Bishop Baumgartner July 25, 1949 5. Lowell Thomas from Tokyo, interview with Emp. staff recorded July 29, 1949

1) Lowell Thomas from Tokyo. Interviews Diet Kamayama and Aitosomatso (August 8, 1949) 2) Lowell Thomas, Jr. repeats on prep. For Tibetan expo. (August 24, 1949) 3) Lowell Thomas from India (August 23, 1949) 4) Lowell Thomas, Jr. from Gangtok. Reports on Avalanche (August 30, 1949)
En route 1. Lowell Thomas, Sr. Reports on Emperor of Japan 2. Ride to Tokyo with Colonel Wheeler, Impressions on being side-swiped by bus 3. Letter to Mrs. Thomas
En route 1. Lowell Thomas, Sr.; Wake is FM Air 2. Story of Typhoon 3. Clipper Skipper makes tower check 4. Arv. Wake Island 5. Reference to Bill Odom, Deve Senter, Hearst Story. 6. LT FM Plain

1. En route- Yatung 2. Lowell Thomas, Jr. - Drama - Celebration 3. Lowell Thomas, Sr. - 6th Days March - Crosses world’s highest peak - ski possibilities 4. Lowell Thomas, Sr. - Visits Hong Kong - Wild Irishman, BBC Head. Nudist Colony - “Corny Roosevelt - Smuggling - Present day China. 5. Lowell Thomas, Sr. - Caravan Bells - “Red Arrow” letter - Gangtok - First to have Tibetan stamp on passport - various interviews - first Tibetan monastery.

1. Yatung, Gatsu, Lhasa 2. Lowell Thomas, Jr. - At Indian trade agent’s house at Yatung - Egg story - scarves - “Passport” translation. (17 day - 6th month, Tibetan bull year) - Isolation - Lowell Thomas, Sr. describes scene of broadcast at Gatsu 3. At splice: Sound effects from festival at Lhasa - singing and symbols - Lowell Thomas, Jr. visits Dalai Lama’s family

1) Lowell Thomas from Mountains of Sikkim, Mr. Deal reports on Butanese (September 1, 1949) 2) Lowell Thomas, Jr. reports from Tibet. Roberts reports to Gangtok. Senior and Junior on to Yatung, over Natu La Pass into Tibet from India (September 7, 1949) 3) Lowell Thomas en route Yatung reports on scenery, polyandry & polygamy (September 12, 1949) 4) Lowell Thomas first report on Chinese in Tibet (September 15, 1949) 5) Duplicate of number 4 with speed corrected 6) Lowell Thomas, Jr. reports from Kala Tibet. Scene of British war with Tibet - Doti Remshi (September 19, 1949)

1) Lowell Thomas reports on trip across High Plateau along caravan route from Kala to Kangma. Sound effects deleted (September 20, 1949) 2) Senior and Junior report on Tibetan passports (September 23, 1949) 3) Lowell Thomas reports on trip along gorges from Shang Lo Chu to Gyantse, visits Remshi Lo Shang Sowan and monastery (September 27, 1949) 4) Lowell Thomas, Jr. reports on marches from Gyantse to Gobshi. Report on mineral wealth. Greeted by nobleman (September 29, 1949) 5) Lowell Thomas, Jr. regarding Neapso Pass. 16,200 feet out of Petti. Lake Yam Oroxso and fish story. First sees Brahmaputra 6) Lowell Thomas from Yak-skin boat in middle of Brahmaputra. Boatmen and paddle sound effects at Chuso, 2 days from Lhasa (October 4, 1949)

1) Lowell Thomas, Jr. regarding approaching Lhasa - at Shingdonka. Report on difficulties en route from Chuku. View of Potala (October 5, 1949) 2) Lowell Thomas arrival at Lhasa. Recap of trip. Quartered on outskirts with Zong of Donka trip into Lhasa, impressions of Drepung. Reception formalities. Dorchi Cheng Gopa story and bit about Potala (October 6, 1949) 3) Lowell Thomas Senior and Junior report on festival at Lhasa (voice only) 4) Lowell Thomas Senior and Junior report on festival at Lhasa - first day in Lhasa, customs broken first time in history. Permission to photo festival. Lowell Thomas, Jr. reports on drama and Lhasa with sound effects (October 7, 1949)

1. Tibetan kitchen - girl spinning wool - food (malfunction) 2. Lowell Thomas, Jr. - S.E. Tibetan music (edited) - singing? - Beggar -Horn atop monastery - Flute At splice: 3. Lowell Thomas, Jr. - Kalla(?) Tibet - 47 miles from Fari altitude 15,000 feet (Fort Farizong?) 4. Views town and people 5. Voti Remshe 6. Yaks 7. Chinese meal with chopsticks 8. Rescues U.S. fliers 9. Chumolari

1) Lowell Thomas repeats on story of Chinese ouster from Tibet and interview with Tibetan Minister at Lhasa, Sircan Laza (10-10-49) 2) Lowell Thomas repeats on Theos Bernard (October 11, 1949) 3) Lowell Thomas repeats on audience with Dalai Lama. First pictures of Dalai Lama. First S.E. on the spot. Colorful procession. Presents for Dalai Lama. Horn on roof. Blessing by Dalai Lama. Diamond Sow - thunder bolt. Dalai Lama’s full name (October 12, 1949) 4) Same as number 3 without sound effects of horn

1) Lowell Thomas, Jr. repeats on “photographic spree,” taking pictures of Dalai Lama, repeats on interview with Regent Tokra and story of his rise to power. Describes pictures taken of Dalai Lama and party, Impressions of Dalai Lama (October 13, 1949) 2) Lowell Thomas, Jr. with Dalai Lama’s family, Drama S.E. (October 19, 1949) 3) Lowell Thomas, Jr. at Chokon - Images of Buddha Monks chant (deep), Story of temple. Prayer wheels (October 21, 1949) 4) Lowell Thomas, Jr. on American goods in Lhasa. Story of attempts to electrify country and equipment destruction (October 25, 1949) 5) Lowell Thomas, Jr. on foods along Tibetan trail (October 28, 1949) 6) Lowell Thomas, Jr. on accident to Lowell Thomas (October 14, 1949)

Drums and flute, drums and pipes (mostly drums), boatmen song, Lowell Thomas, Jr. on army, (1 sentence) Lowell Thomas, Jr. on last day of festival, describes ride to ceremonies, story of drama. Parts of Tibetan trip to America. Monks chanting. Boat sequence (Lowell Thomas voice only). Lowell Thomas, Jr. short bit on views of Lhasa. Lowell Thomas word from Gyantse. Procedure for mailing there, mention of Doctor Paul - Captain Petrill. McGovern story (not used on air)
Lowell Thomas, Jr. Tibet (letters from wire) 1. Lowell Jr. on Tibet 2. Letters to various people 3. Transcribed from Webcor Wire to 3.75 inches per second
About Tashi Lama, Warren Hasting story, Lowell Thomas, Jr. reports on conversations with Tibetans, Zaza Lama, Sircon Zaza report on core of Tibetan life, Visits monasteries Sara, gonda and Drepung
Reel #2 To Yatung, Monks, first monastery in Tibet, Grey monkey, Chumby

Reel #3 Lowell Thomas, Jr. speaks, young husband story, brief on Rhododren, Doochers, Tomorrow Tibet Lowell Thomas, Sr. speaks, Second Days March, at Chungu, report on trip, mules antics, whistle, flower studies, mountains of Sikkim, monkshood story, tiger story, throwing rocks at devils, sawongs shout at devils, note from Lowell Thomas
Reel #4 Lowell Thomas, Jr. speaks, story of joke heard while in air force and recalled while crossing Natu La Pass, shaggy dog
Reel #5 Lowell Thomas, Jr. speaks, Impressions of Lhasa

Lowell Thomas, senior; Repeat from steps of India, Government Agency in Yatung; meets first Tibetan; Story of country, no. 1 trade agent; cross Natu La Pass; to Yatung; Polyandry; (recorded at slow speed)

Lowell Thomas, senior; Gentlemen of the Imperial Court; status of former title holders Lowell Thomas, junior; longest days march (14 hours); fourteenth day of marching, twenty two days from Calcutta; seventh day from Gangtok Ralung to Nagarisi via Caro La Pass. Diamond sow not met due to floods.
Lowell Thomas, senior; notes of effects of morphing; way tapes are sent out in relays condition of leg.

Lowell Thomas, junior; repeat on Monasteries at Sari and visit to main temple; Buddhist beliefs. Lowell Thomas, senior; richest man in Tibet; Sarong shape (Nang-Kur) personal notes; making sedan chair
Lowell Thomas, junior; Stage number 1 to Lhasa. Dak Bungalows; 10,000 feet; 290 miles from Lhasa. Story of trip; supplies, and others. (Beggar deleted)

Lowell Thomas, junior; portion of impressions of D.L. (edited); Boatmen (portion only); Brahmaputra paddles and chant Lowell Thomas, senior; four days from Lhasa. Lowell Thomas, junior; local color Lowell Thomas, senior; cooking on trail. Broadcast from yak-skin boat in middle of Brahmaputra.
Starts with short bit (edited) by Lowell Thomas, junior. Lowell Thomas, junior; telephone line in Tibet (low level), chop off hands, no wheels in Tibet

Lowell Thomas, junior; at Gyantse; Living in Tibetan homes; along swollen streams; prayer flags across Gorge, rich man and entourage Lowell Thomas, senior; personal notes Lowell Thomas, junior; note to Mary
Tibet number 4, as done on lecture platform with both music and voice
Lowell Thomas, Jr. 1949, sound effects - distortion, low level; Iran - Lowell Thomas, Jr. - Baktiari Tribes - (incomplete), Lowell Thomas, Sr. on end - note to Prosper Recorded in Tibet
Band at Lhasa sound effects, pipes, drums and more
Chanting with bagpipes and other instruments
Horn on Top of Building
Lowell Thomas, Jr. Sound Effects, Tibet 1949 [1] Horn, various group music
Lowell Thomas, Jr. Sound Effects, Tibet 1949 [2] Horn, various group music
Various sound effects recorded at Lhasa Festival

Leaving Calcutta; preparations; Sealda h Railway Station; riots at station; Robbery defense; Sighting Himalayas; Kangchenjunga, over 28,000 ft; Siliguri; bypassing Darjeeling Railway; 70 miles by car to Gangtok; Avalanche; Tibet Broadcast[stand alone copy somewhere]: Stranded in Sikkim, 3 day monsoon, lost sight of Kangchenjunga, delayed because of expedition preparations, Bhutan treaty, first post-British Bhutan treaty Lowell Thomas, Jr. Tibet Broadcast: Expected 10 hours to Gangtok, Rock Slide, 200ft covering road, ¼ wide, retreat to bungalow, stones still sliding down the next day, day late to Gangtok Lowell Thomas Jr. Tibet Breadcast: completed 10 miles through Sikkimese Jungle, 10,000 ft above sea level; 290 miles left, 14 days; pack animals, singing beggar, constant monsoon rains, 250in annual rainfall, following main trade path from Tibet to outside world

Lowell Thomas, Jr, “from the top of the world:” 5 miles from Lhasa, High flood waters, failure of pack animals through sludge, first day without rain, waided through flood, Donkeys up to ears in water, some forced to swim; reached Tibetan Highway #1, dirt path; sight of Lhasa Lowell Thomas from Lhasa: Ousting of Chinese, lack of journalistic coverage, word of mouth, one radio center for international broadcasts, warm welcome, were told full story, History of Chinese involvement in Tibet, cuts off…

Lowell Thomas from Tibet: Meeting with Dalai Lama, recorded motion pictures and audio, gifts to Dalai Lama Lowell Thomas, Jr. from Tibet: traditions broken for Thomas party, concerned about communists, friendly towards America; Young Lama to assume total power at 18, 72 year old Regent, story of reactionary regency, revolt by Chinese, Buddhist Monks fighting government, Meeting with Dalai Lama, “the D.L.,” even got pictures of Lama on Throne, yellow-peaked cap, both feared and loved Lowell Thomas, Jr. Leaving Tibet: 5 days from Holy City, goal to reach New York by October 1st, Lowell Thomas thrown off horse, high altitude caused concern, landed on hip, no doctor, help days away, rest hard to hear [original may be better condition]

scopecontent.p: South Africa; man who received 266,000 telegrams in response to a single broadcast, Lowell Thomas actually received 265,567 telegrams, largest response to any broadcast, freak incident, Admiral Richard E. Byrd Arctic Expedition with Russell Owen, Owen broadcasted through Littleton, New Zealand, Newcomb Carlton of Western Union, announcer Jimmy Wallington, offered free telegrams to Lowell Thomas, some confused listeners sent telegrams from Postal, a competitor, two thousand telegrams were repeats from May West; was given a live bear for Christmas, kept for awhile then given to a Zoo, jet lag from South Pole16:10

Volume II Edward R. Murrow, Narrator S1:Woodrow Wilson; Warren G. Harding; Calvin Coolidge; Herbert Hoover; Franklin Delano Roosevelt; The Armistice; Wilson and the League: address to the Senate; Wilson goes to the people; Senator Borah and Senator Hiram Johnson oppose the League; Wilson’s last speech; William Allen White on Wilson Tragedy; 1920: Daughterty makes “smoke filled room” prediction; Harding nominated; Harding before inaugural; First election broadcast KDKA; Will Rogers comments of U.S. Senate; Harding as President: after six months, after one year, after sixteen months, after twenty-six months; Harding death announced by George Christian; Coolidge sworn in Vermont farmhouse; Harding eulogy by Bishop Manning; Senator Walsh opens Teapot Dome investigations; Secretary Fall and E. L. Doheny before Walsh Committee; 1924 Democratic Convention; Coolidge after Inaugural; Montage of American customs and behavior in the early twenties; Ted Husing describes Babe Ruth home run; Grantland Rice of “The Four Horsemen”; Coolidge on War debts, 1923 S2: The Scopes trial at Dayton, Tennessee, William Jennings Bryan and Clarence Darrow; Gene Tunney becomes new heavyweight champion; Graham MacNamee call[sic] famous “long count” round in second Tunney-Dempsey fight; Lindbergh takes off in “Spirit of St. Louis,” progress of flight reported by George Hicks, Lowell Thomas and others; Jimmy Walker welcomes Lindburgh, more Walker greetings, Queen Marie, Bobby Jones, Gertrude Eder; Quincy Howe reports execution of Sacco and Vanzetti; Review of Sacco-Vanzetti cans and Vanzetti’s last statement, the Prohibition era; “Radio is here to stay”; Amos and Andy, Bing Crosby, Rudy Vallee, Will Rogers; Coolidge declines renomination; Hoover on prosperity; FDR nominates Al Smith; Smith campaigns on “wet” issue; Boom and bust: the stock market crash and the depression; Robert Trout announces Democratic victory in’32; Franklin Delano Roosevelt’s first inaugural

S1: 1. Franklin Delano Roosevelt Inaugural Address, March 4th, 1933 2. King Edward VIII, Abdication, December 11th, 1936 3. Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain returns from Munich, September 27th, 1938 4. Chamberlain, Radio Broadcast on war with Germany, September 3rd, 1939 5. Prime Minister Winston Churchill, Radio Address to Great Britain, May 13th, 1940 6. Prime Minister Churchill, Broadcast to Europe, October 21st, 1940 7. Radio Bulletin on Pearl Harbor, December 7th, 1941 8. President Roosevelt, Address to Joint Session of Congress, December 8th, 1941 9. Prime Minister Churchill, Address to Canadian Parliament, December 30th, 1941 10. General Douglas MacArthur in Australia, 1944 11. General Dwight A. Eisenhower, Radio Broadcast to Europe, D-Day, June 6th, 1944 12. President Harry S. Truman, Announcement of German Surrender, May 8th, 1945 13. General Eisenhower, Broadcast to U.S. Troops May 8th, 1945 14. Prime Minister Churchill, Radio Address to the British People, May 8th, 1945 15. King George VI Broadcast, May 8th, 1945 16. U.S.S.R. Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov at United Nations Conference in San Francisco, May 8th, 1945 17. Prayer before take-off of B-29 “Enola Gay” for Hiroshima, August 6th, 1945 18. President Truman, Radio Broadcast on new Atomic Age, August 9th, 1945 S2: 19. General MacArthur accepts Japanese Surrender, September 1st, 1945 20. Winston Churchill, Speech at Fulton, Missouri, March 5th, 1946 21. Secretary of State George Catlett Marshall, Speech at Harvard University, June 5th, 1947 22. Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Radio Address on the death of Mohandas K. Gandhi, January 30th, 1948 23. Representative Joseph W. Martin, Jr. introduces Candidate Dwight D. Eisenhower at Republican Convention, July 11th, 1952 24. Candidate Eisenhower accepts the nomination 25. president Eisenhower, Press Conference in Korea, December 5th, 1952 26. The Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II, June 2nd, 1953 27. President Eisenhower, Report on the Geneva Summit Conference, July 24th, 1955 28. Bishop of Monaco, Wedding of Prince Rainier III and Grace Kelly, April 19th, 1956 29. Last Radio Broadcast, Hungarian Freedom Fighters, November 1st, 1956 30. Sputnik signal, October 4th, 1957 31. Moscow Radio announcement on Sputnik I, October 4th, 1957 32. Countdown as Jupiter C Missile launches American satellite, January 31st, 1958
